The more precise we know a particle's momentum, the less precise we know its position argument is quite intuitive because once we know the particle is in motion, it will be difficult to measure its position in space because it will keep changing. The more precise we know a particle's position, the less we know about its momentum argument could be explained using the following: we see a particle but am not sure if it's at rest or in motion (whether constant or accelerating) because motion is relative and there's no inertial frame of reference around to compare the particle's motion to, thus, making it difficult to measure its precise momentum.

When you find the wavelength of the base ball, you use the equation p=mv and  p=h/ λ together. But the first equation is based on newtonian physics(mass can't change, space and time is absolute); while the second one is based on special relativity(mass can change, space and time is not absolute). Dont you think one can't use the two together as the two are applicable in very different conditions.                                                                                   -Chinmay Kulkarni

it doesn't. but still you need to know all attributes of a existing moving body. wen at rest you can say it has this mass, this velocity, this momentum, this position etc. but something is set in motion, especially small particles, you loose the ability to measure all of it at once. so, imagine a moving car at a very high speed.   you can physically see it moving, but can't tell it's exact position anymore, if you do. that means at that point it is not moving, so you can't measure it's velocity anymore. same thing with mass, a moving body has a different mass than one in motion. hence using the terms, momentum and position uncertainty.

Could we have an objective understanding of quantum mechanics if we explained it as an emergent interactive process unfolding photon by photon? This idea is based on: (E=ˠM˳C²)∞ with energy ∆E equals mass ∆M linked to the Lorentz contraction ˠ of space and time. The Lorentz contraction ˠ represents the time dilation of Einstein’s Theory of Relativity. We have energy ∆E slowing the rate that time ∆t flows as a universal process of energy exchange or continuous creation. Mass will increase relative to this process with gravity being a secondary force to the electromagnetic force. The c² represents the speed of light c radiating out in a sphere 4π of EMR from its radius forming a square c² of probability. We have to square the probability of the wave-function Ψ because the area of the sphere is equal to the square of the radius of the sphere multiplied by 4π. This simple geometrical process forms the probability and uncertainty of everyday life and at the smallest scale of the process is represented mathematically by Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle ∆×∆pᵪ≥h/4π. In such a theory we have an emergent future unfolding photon by photon with the movement of charge and flow of EM fields. This gives us a geometrical reason for positive and negative charge with a concaved inner surface for negative charge and a convexed outer surface for positive charge. The brackets in the equation (E=ˠM˳C²)∞ represent a dynamic boundary condition of an individual reference frame with an Arrow of Time or time line for each frame of reference. The infinity ∞ symbol represents an infinite number of dynamic interactive reference frames that are continuously coming in and out of existence.

Heisenberg's uncertainty principle makes intuitive sense to me. When something moves a lot, you're less certain about where it is at any point in time--it could accelerate, friction might apply, the thing might slow. But if it isn't moving too much, then you can tell where it is more accurately. Now, though, its speed is hard to measure; if it's slow enough, you might not measure movement at all!  For super small particles, like on the quantum level, this uncertainty is so pronounced that you can't ever know position and momentum.

The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle says you can't derive a precise momentum from a position measurement or vice versa. It's a property of the math, not of matter. Therefore it doesn't rule out taking precise measurements of both position and momentum. You can know precisely about both, if you measure them quickly one after the other. https://youtu.be/rciVgQm-F_U

I think you're confused about the source of the interference.  Imagine firing electrons at the double slit so slowly that  each electron reaches the back wall before the next electron is fired.  If you do this for a long time so that many electrons are fired through the slits, one after the other, and then make a plot of the distribution of their locations on the back wall, you'll find that the distribution exhibits the same interference pattern.  Clearly the electron is not interacting with other electrons as it passes through the slit because you only fire one at a time.  Electrons can be spread out over a region of space so that they are not located at any one point; that is what we mean by the wave nature of electrons.  When the electron (the wave) passes through the slits, it acquires the interference pattern, just like any other wave.  It isn't until the wave hits the back wall that it collapses to a point (i.e. it becomes a "particle.")

When we study elemental mechanics, we make certain assumptions. Like we take ground to be conservative ground and have relative velocity 0 w.r.t. it. But is it always true? Does earth, when rotates not produce any kinetic energy and thus be non-conservative? It does, it is VERY negligible but it is. Taking big objects like a car, the effect on them is almost 0 but for atoms, that SMALL assumption goes a long way, hence the uncertainty. Now as you must've got by now, The De Broglie Wavelength can get small with high mass and high for less velocity... But thinking about it....Nothing is ever at rest! Hope you get it now Buahra...

It has to do with the uncertainty principle, that is ΔpₓΔx ≥ ħ/2, where Δpₓ is the uncertainty in momentum in the x direction, Δx is the uncertainty in the position along the x direction, and ħ ("h bar" is Planck's constant = 1.054572 x 10⁻³⁴). An object's location can be determined by visual inspection within an uncertainty of approximately 550nm, visible light. If we are looking at a stationary object, for example a ping-pong ball with mass of 0.0027kg, the minimum uncertainty in the momentum is given by Δpₓ(5.5x10⁻⁷m)=(1.005x10⁻³⁴Js)÷2 Δpₓ=9.59x10⁻²⁹kg m/s. This means the minimum uncertainty in the velocity is Δv=Δp÷m Δv=(9.59x10⁻²⁹kg m/s)÷0.0027kg Δv=3.55x10⁻²⁶ In order for the ping-pong ball to move a perceivable distance, 1μm, it would take t=distance÷speed t=10⁻⁶m÷(3.55x10⁻²⁶m/s) t=2.815x10²⁰s  or 89 billion centuries. Clearly this is clearly a long enough time to know the position and velocity precisely enough to use classical mechanics. But according to quantum mechanics and the uncertainty principle, if the ping ping ball were known exactly to have 0 velocity this would imply the uncertainty in position is infinite. Since we know that we are able to perceive the location of the ping pong we must surmise that the ping ping ball does have some velocity. So even though the ping pong ball is not actually stationary, its motion is imperceivable.  Compare the earlier calculations to an electron with a mass of 9.11x10⁻³¹kg moving around an atom with size 0.1x10⁻⁹m. In this case the minimum uncertainty in momentum Δpₓ=5.3x10⁻²⁵kg m/s and Δv=(5.3x10⁻²⁵kg m/m)÷9.11x10⁻³¹kg= 5.8x10x10⁵m/s already we can see that the minimum uncertainty in velocity is much higher. In order for an electron to move a distance of 1μm it would only take  t=10⁻⁶m÷5.8x10⁵m/s = 1.724x10⁻¹¹s From this we can get some intuition behind why the movement of an electron is difficult to pinpoint.

Here's my justification for the measurement problem of electrons.  Math is naive, and measurement, for anything that exists, is wrong.  It's not that the electrons' behavior is counter intuitive, it's our mathematics that is counter intuitive.  The act of measuring a location of anything is fundamentally wrong; it just doesn't make sense to try and measure a location of something.  In fact, there is nothing that says that our universe has to fit into the rules of our logical thinking, quite the contrary I'd say.  And in fact, to me, this is an intuitive way of thinking. Why should our reality fit into neat boxes convenient for human beings to think about?   It just doesn't make sense that it would in the first place.  We're not that great, afterall, we're just a bunch of apes running around a big rock with trees (and we can't even tell that those rocks and trees are actually a bundle of moving particles without magnification -- and even then, there is doubt about our sense-perception in the first place.  But you know, it is amazing that we ourselves are just a bundle of particles, yet we have identity and behavior and consciousness; and that is truly amazing).

I think this is actually obvious given that I grew up learning about modern chemistry in grade school.  I suppose it's a big leap for old timers, but for me I have always found the simplicity of classical mechanics absurd and suspect. Maybe this will change as we probe smaller and smaller phenomena, but I do think that our continuous thinking will have to be abolished in the future and I find quantum phenomena to be not only intuitive, but actually the correct way to think in general.

Seems to me that the confusion lies in saying things ARE waves, when this isnt true. An electron and a photon are not waves, they BEHAVE like waves. When you swing a rope to visualize the wave traveling through it, there's no rope moving, just the wave. A wave is a a function behavior that depends on time as a parameter, and so they can't be something at any exclusive moment of time.  It doesn't make sense to say the electron was everywhere until we observed. Probabilities are just a measurement of ignorance and dictates what we should do, it says nothing about the system. Is it going to rain 99% probability? Bring an umbrella, but you still are not sure if it's going to rain. So why do clever and smart scientists keep pushing around that quantum mechanics are weird because of wave-particle theory? It should be because of the vector and matrix interpretation of what were once scalars. Electrons and photons are particles, and they behave like waves when interacting which each other. One single electron can't form a wave pattern, much like a single molecule of a rope can't represent a wave.

Great video again and I am glad this series goes as deep into physics as quantum mechanics. There are only two points I am missing: Observation in physics always involves interaction. To measure the position of an particle you need photons (or other particles) with a very small wavelength and therefore high energy. If this isn't stressed enough many people tend to think of some metaphysical force how the particle "knows" that it's watched. It's not about a conscious observer it's interaction that collapses the wave function. The same goes for Schroedingers cat. The cat itself is a macroscopic entity made of trillions of particles interacting. To be in real superposition a particle needs to be shielded from interaction. Of course Schroedingers point was to make an analogy how absurd it would be on a macroscopic scale but that is prevented by quantum mechanic itself. The cat or even the apparatus that releases the poison is the observer. Now the analogy also helps to foster this esoteric quantum woo that connects observation to consciousness.

Actually, there's no such thing as a "wave", physically speaking. Waves are configurations of parameters, not an object or thing.

My point is that the behavior of particles as waves shouldn't be confused with them being waves. If a single electron hit a wall, it hit the wall, so it will never show any wave like behavior. A wave function is dependent on time, and its quite obvious that particles are altering the system, leaving a mark or trails behind that interferes with the particles that come next. The observer effect is a bit misleading, it implies observation alone. Measurement is still required to know where exactly that electron is, once you take a measurement, you have the position which you cannot predict. This also does not mean the electron stays frozen while you're observing and measuring it, it don't give a dang who be lookin', an electron's gotta do what an electron's gotta do.  It's easier to wrap your head around once you realise you cannot observe something you cannot see with the naked eye :)  If the observer effect worked as implied, than things would stop while observed in classical physics just like weeping angels.

Omg I never intuitively understood wave/particle duality before, but i just thought about something... What if there was no intrinsic duality, i.e. Particles themselves are never waves and can't ever be "collapsed". All particles are always only particles. However, their existence, or like, their "ability to be" somewhere with a certain momentum is what's a wave.  So, like, in the photon and electron slit experiments  the particles themselves are always just particles and never actually interfere or interact with each other at all. Instead, what interferes is the particle's "ability to be" at particular locations.  This isn't incompatible with the tiny amount of quantum mechanics I've been able to pick up from popsci media, but it would mean that the universe makes sense without needing to understand what the universe counts as an "observation" events - I.e. What kinds of interactions are able to collapse wave functions. In turn that would mean that scenarios like "collapse cascades" aren't a thing.

This is another fun consequence of QM. It's impossible for something to have 0 momentum. If it had 0 momentum, you would know its momentum for sure, which means it would have infinite position uncertainty. This is why we can't cool things to absolute zero.

Yeah, I was a little disappointed that she didn't clarify that, considering how often the Observer Effect is misrepresented by both ignorant people and charlatans alike.

+K Dov You can't do quantum mechanics without observers, but you can certainly do it without conscious observers. The term "observation" in quantum mechanics simply refers to any interaction between particles.

+K Dov It has nothing at all to do with knowledge. That kind of misunderstanding is the reason we get people like Deepak Chopra using what one professor on Sixty Symbols once called "quantum woo" (stating that there's something metaphysical about a mind because it's required for the observer effect...even though it's not).   Specifically: the measurement problem has nothing to do with knowledge, but about measurement. And there's no way (that we know of yet) to measure something without interacting with it. Hence, if you measure something, you've interacted with it, and the interaction is what causes the collapse--the interaction is an observation.  The delayed choice quantum eraser experiment is also not about knowledge; you may be interpreting it as being about a conscious decision having an effect on the quantum state, but that's not what it is, either. Once again, this experiment is about measurement. The way you measure a quantum object determines the way it manifests (as either a wave or a particle). The delayed choice experiment assumes that the photon (in the most common form of it) has already manifested as either a particle or a wave upon its creation, and then changing how you measure it somehow changes that manifestation, thereby assuming that your measurement in the present "altered" the manifestation in the past when the photon was created. That's where the paradox comes in. But it's only a paradox if you assume the photon was in either a wave or particle state from the beginning, and more recent experiments have shown that's not the case. In reality, the photon is in a superposition--that is, it's a wave and a particle at the same time. Only once it's measured does it collapse into one state or the other, so your decision on how to measure it after its creation doesn't matter, only the way in which it ends up being measured--again, it's about how the interaction occurs, not any kind of knowledge, decision, or consciousness.  And there's no such thing as "interaction free collapse", at least not as far as I can find any information about; the closest thing I've found talks about "interaction free measurements", but it specifically explains that they're not truly free of interaction, only minimized interactions (and from what I can tell, the definition of "interaction free measurement" here means "interactions are only with virtual particles"--but that still means interactions are occurring!).

Unfortunately an "observer" IS a mind. If an "observer" were just any interaction, then the wave function would collapse all the time from countless interactions occurring every moment. The idea that you'd ever find a wave function that's not yet collapsed implies that the "observer" must be a mind.   This is preposterous, which is why Schrodinger came up with the hypothetical cat experiment. He was trying to demonstrate to his colleagues how dangerous it is to go down the road of wild ad hoc hypothesis instead of hard science. Instead his colleagues thought he was agreeing that magic is real.
@daemonCaptrix have you ever looked at chemical reactions? Billions of observers and interactions happening every second and no minds were needed.

A wave packet is kind of an intermediate wave function that sits between a "particle wave" (where the wave is clustered at a single point, with indeterminate momentum) and a pure sine wave that spreads out over the whole universe (which has a well-defined momentum but no position).  It has both a reasonably well-defined position and a reasonably well-defined momentum.  Free particles (i.e. particles that aren't bound into an atom) are expected to spend most of their time in this kind of state.

I would like to propose that a photon's wavelength is also its De Broglie wavelength, if indeed a photon can have a De Broglie wavelength.  Since my keyboard doesn't have the Greek letter lambda for wavelength, I will substitute L for lambda.  Further, c is the speed of light, E is energy, f is frequency, h is Planck's constant, m is mass, p is momentum, and v is velocity.  The De Broglie equation is L = h/p.  Also, the wavelength of a photon is found through E =hf = hc/L, so L = hc/E.  Additionally, E =m(c**2) (or m(c squared)).  Therefore, L= hc/mcc = h/mc.  p = mv, so for a photon, p = mc.  In conclusion, I get L = h/p for both the wavelength of a photon and its De Broglie wavelength.  One problem is that photons don't actually have mass, because they are traveling at the speed of light.  However, they do seem to have momentum, as light can actually push or move an object, such as a photon sail proposed by those speculating on modes of space travel.  (How can a photon have momentum without mass, and what are your thoughts on this?)  Anyway, assuming for the purpose of showing that a photon's wavelength is also its De Broglie wavelength that a photon does have mass, the equations match up.

For those curious about the Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, it's a direct consequence from Fourier transformation. As explained in the video, we need to think of the particle as waves (having momentum) or particles (having position). The Fourier transform let's you go between these different spaces (momentum space / position space) but it kind of "bundles up" a range of values into a single value when changing space, and that gives you the uncertainty.   For example, imagine a sinus wave, just a wavy rope going from the left to right. Now, rotate your viewing position to one end of the rope so that the wave travels straight from your position. From this point, it would look like a vertical line. So even if the wave was very irregular with different heights at different nodes, from this perspective, we would only see a single vertical line. We have thus "bundled up" a range of different values, and we can't be certain what the height of the rope would be at different positions, but we know it's within the range of our vertical line.  So the uncertainty principle is a purely mathematical restriction which was known long before quantum mechanics, but took a practical meaning after the discovery of quantum mechanics.

Here is my interpretation of an example of uncertainty:  If a particle A is detected, it has been struck by a photon B or let's say an electron B.  B ricochets off of A and next strikes the human eye, the electron microscope, or whatever (the dectector, so to speak).  The eye or microscope registers the collision of B with itself.  However, the data can only suggest where A was at the time B struck it and bounced off.  In the meantime, A will have moved.  Not only that, B's collision with A will have caused A to bounce away from where it was, change trajectory, or both.  While we might be able to predict about where A might be, the data suggested by the collision of B with the detector will be at least slightly in error, unless A is so large that an overwhelming cancellation of forces due to many naturally occurring collisions causes the collision of B with A to have a negligible effect on the position and/or trajectory of A.  However, if A is very small, the uncertainty increases.  Of course if A is much more massive than B, this factor will also decrease the effect on A of B's collision with A.

+Ley Fagarita It really depends on what level you are on and how deep you want to go. If you know calculus and linear algebra then you can jump in on the "proper" textbooks, otherwise it's probably best to read conceptual ones or learn the maths first. For basic mechanics, I've heard that "Newtonian Mechanics" by A.P. French should be great. After that I would recommend "Classical Mechanics" by H. Goldstein. After that you should have a good foundation to tackle quantum mechanics. I would recommend either "Quantum Mechanics: A Modern Development" by L. Ballentine or "Modern Quantum Mechanics" By J. Sakurai.  Good luck! If you do learn physics, I guarantee you it will be one of the most rewarding things you'll do in life! :D

Schrodinger's cat is stupid thought experiment, because in quantum world "measurement" equals "interaction between particles". So the "measurement" happened exactly when the series of quantum events leading to cat's death started.
damn... i just found it interesting but whatever man im no physicist :D

That's why it's so weird. The only way to get the probability to work out in these instances is to think of the electron being simultaneously at every spot, but once it is known, it is 100% in that spot all the time. That's where the measuring it changes it comes from.

The dual-slit experiment demonstrates that superposition is observably different from simply not knowing where the particle is i.e. it produces an interference pattern. In principle, you can measure some sort of interference effect showing that Schrodinger's cat was, at some time, neither alive nor dead.

I'm pretty sure pilot-wave theory goes into this and debunks the whole dead cat things. A good start would be Vertasiums video "is this what quantum mechanics looks like" which helped me visualize the basic, dulled down concept. The theory goes into explaining the interference pattern in the double slit and more, it's quite amazing.

That Pilot-wave video is a great way to visualize what's happening but that doesn't mean what you are seeing is what's happening at the quantum scale. The other way of expressing this (that she never mentioned) is that an observation causes the wave function to collapse. Also, I don't see how pilot-wave theory explains the kind of quantum behavior where the particle appears outside of a boundary (in transistors) or how protonation occurs in molecules.

The Copenhagen interpretation is false. Schrodinger's cat is intended to demonstrate that fact. There is no such thing as superposition, only imperfect measurement. That's because things that are inconsistent across physics MUST be false or flawed.
Thank you all for the interesting comments. I will be checking the videos out. :)

Physicist here. While pilot wave theory being fun and all to make videos about, it carries no value at this time. It doesn't predict any effect quantum mechanics doesn't, and math is so complicated that everyone gave up on describing known effects. Pilot wave theory is a joke at the moment. On one hand Copenhagen (or any other accepted interpretation) of quantum mechanics: - Hard to understand model - which been amazingly successful allowing us to build computers - describe all know particle effects - predicted a bunch of new effects confirmed with experiments - has more or less approachable math which allows us to do everything above On other hand Pilot wave theory: - looks simple at first glance for ape brain which must have stuff hitting stuff - doesn't predict anything new - have really hard time describing anything past double slit experiment - math gets complex so hard so fast that no one cares about it - no practical value - Veratasium dude made youtube vid about it  Did I miss something?  I, and pretty much any other physicist, doesn't think pilot wave hypothesis even as a "theory" because it fails to make any observable prediction.

Vlad Svoka - That's how a theory works. It's a collection of information. The leading theory is the one that explains the most relevant things. I don't think the Pilot Wave Theory will eventually lead. But I do know that a good theory will never contradict known physics. If there's a single hole, then the whole thing is wrong.   That said, I trust that physicists know what they're doing, but I fear there's some sensationalism going on. It's impossible by definition for a thing to be a particle and a wave. PLEASE tell me the assertion that photons are both a particle and a wave is just placeholder wording and is not meant to be taken literally. :(

Quantum mechanics involves both particles and waves, but "a particle and a wave" is not a good description of anything. Particles appear to us as probabilistic events, and waves determine the probabilities of those events. There is no agreement on how to interpret things beyond that.
Well we dont know exactly what they "are" but we know it can act as both, but until new evidence comes it has to be taken literally in the maths.

Problem with Pilot Waves that they fail to predict anything. Unlike Quantum Physics, which did astounding number of predictions, which we measured and verified and using... To be a true theory, it must predict at least some behaviours, but for not it's like colouring book, trying to describe already known, which has 0 worth.

Miaaaou yup, caused by diffraction

Well diffraction and interference aren't really the same...  Diffraction appears because of the shape of the slit (or more, but with only one, you only get diffraction, no interference) the light goes through and Interference is the "interference" between two (or more) waves (constructive or destructive)

Well, it's the diffraction that causes the pattern of interferences. So the interferences themselves aren't that interesting, it's the pattern in which they occur in, caused by the diffraction that is interesting.

Two waves of the same frequency pass through each other. Which is an interference pattern. The after math once the pattern hits the wall is the diffraction pattern. Which you can only get from an inference pattern.

Diffraction patterns are caused by interference. For example for light in double slit diffraction, the path difference between the rays (one from top slit and one from bottom, assuming slits are delta functions) at any point on the screen will cause destructive or constructive interference (or somewhere in between )
